CHAPTER 31: The Distribution of Conquest

Date: Late November 1431
Location: Royal Palace, Jaén

You find Álvaro in the administrative chambers overlooking Jaén's ramparts, surrounded by maps of western Granada marked with garrison positions and supply routes. The evening light catches dust motes drifting through the window as he studies the conquered territories with the focused intensity you've come to recognize.

He looks up as you enter, setting down his quill. "Your Majesty." A slight smile. "The budget is complete, the Cortes satisfied. Now you're thinking about how to keep what we've taken without bankrupting the crown on garrison costs."

When you present your proposal—estates for tax-paying nobles and proven newcomers, distributing the ports and fortresses, preserving Málaga's municipal rights—Álvaro's eyes narrow thoughtfully. He traces a finger along the coastal fortifications on the map.

"It's brilliant," he says flatly. "And it solves multiple problems at once." He taps Málaga. "Keep the city's fuero—smart. A grateful merchant city pays better taxes than a grasping lord. They'll defend their own privileges fiercely." His finger moves to the smaller coastal forts. "These? Perfect for rewarding loyalty. A fortress on the coast, productive hinterlands, trade income—valuable enough to inspire competition among nobles for your favor."

He straightens, arms crossed. "The new nobility angle—that's where you'll face resistance. Every old house will scream about 'upstarts' and 'diluting noble blood.'" A dry smile. "I'd know something about that. But Your Majesty, it's also your shrewdest move. Create nobles who owe everything to you, not ancient family alliances. They'll be loyal because their legitimacy depends on your continued favor."

He pauses, then adds: "Three questions before we proceed: First, how do we define 'loyal' and 'current on taxes' without seeming arbitrary? Second, what size estates are we considering—and do recipients provide their own garrisons, or do we subsidize? Third—" his tone sharpens slightly "—have you thought about who specifically you want elevated to new nobility? Because that decision will echo for generations."

Date: Mid-February 1432
Location: Royal Palace, Toledo

Upstairs, Isabel rests with your newborn daughter Catalina. The wet nurse and physicians assure you both are recovering well, though Isabel remains weak.

Fra Giovanni da Fiesole stands before a large drawing board, his Dominican habit paint-stained, a piece of charcoal in his hand. He's perhaps forty-five, thin and ascetic, with an intensity in his dark eyes that speaks of someone who sees beyond the material world. When he notices you, he sets down the charcoal immediately and bows—not with courtly flourish, but with genuine reverence.

I was..." he gestures at the drawing before him, "...trying to understand how the light fell on the banner during your wedding. The prior described it, but I wanted to see if I could capture the moment when sacred objects make light itself holy."

He steps aside so you can see his work. The drawing shows the cathedral interior with remarkable precision—every column, every arch—but what strikes you is how he's sketched rays of light falling across the white banner and the reliquaries, as if the light itself were bowing before the holy objects.

"I have many questions for Your Majesty," Fra Giovanni says, his eyes meeting yours with unexpected directness. "But first—may I ask why you wanted this painted? Not for posterity, I think. Not for glory. There is another reason."

The assembled churchmen fill the vaulted chamber—the most important ecclesiastical gathering in Castile in recent memory. Álvaro had summoned them weeks ago at your request, and they've traveled from across the kingdom.

Archbishop Gutiérrez Álvarez de Toledo sits at the head of the table in his capacity as Primate of Spain, flanked by a dozen bishops and abbots. The mood is tense. Everyone knows what's at stake in Basel.

The Archbishop rises when you enter, and the assembly bows. "Your Majesty. We are assembled as you requested, to discuss the Council of Basel and Castile's participation."

He gestures for you to take the seat of honor. Once you're settled, he continues: "Your Majesty, the situation in Basel grows more troubling by the week. Pope Eugenius IV attempted to dissolve the council in December, but the assembled prelates refused to disperse. They've declared that councils derive authority directly from Christ—not from the Pope—and therefore the Holy Father cannot dissolve them."

Bishop Álvaro de Isorna of Cuenca, an older man with sharp eyes, leans forward. "This is the Hussite heresy all over again, Your Majesty. First they question papal authority in Bohemia. Now French and German bishops question it at Basel. Where does it end?"

But the Bishop of Palencia, younger and more reform-minded, counters: "With respect, my lord of Cuenca, the Council raises legitimate concerns about church governance. The Pope cannot reform the church alone—we've seen how personal interests corrupt. The councils provide checks against abuse."

The Archbishop raises his hand, forestalling argument. "We are not here to debate the theological merits, brothers. We are here because His Majesty must decide: Does Castile send representatives to Basel? And if so, what position do they take?"

He looks at you directly. "Your Majesty, you have unique standing. Pope Martin V blessed your crusade personally. Cardinal Capranica served as your legate. You have papal favor unlike any Iberian monarch in living memory." He pauses. "But the new Pope Eugenius and the Council are at war. You cannot remain neutral. Whatever we do will be noticed in Rome and in Basel."

The Archbishop nods gravely. "A fair question, Your Majesty. Let me explain the crisis we face."

He settles back in his chair. "The issue is not whether we are Christians—we all are. The question is: Who governs the Church? Does ultimate authority rest with the Pope alone, as Vicar of Christ? Or with councils of bishops, who claim to speak for the whole Church?"

Bishop Alfonso de Cartagena of Burgos, known as one of Castile's finest scholars, speaks up. "Your Majesty, to understand the present, we must remember the recent past. From 1378 to 1417—nearly forty years—the Church was torn by schism. Two popes, sometimes three, all claiming to be the true successor of Peter. Rome had one pope, Avignon another. Christendom was divided, each pope excommunicating the other's followers."

The Bishop of Palencia continues the history: "The Council of Constance, which met from 1414 to 1418, resolved this crisis. But how? The council deposed all three competing popes and elected a new one—Pope Martin V, who blessed your crusade. The council declared that it possessed authority directly from Christ, and that even popes must submit to it in matters of faith and church reform."

Archbishop Gutiérrez adds: "The council issued a decree called Haec Sancta—'This Holy Synod.' It stated that councils have their power directly from Christ, and that everyone, including the Pope, must obey them. It also decreed regular councils must be held—every ten years at minimum."

Bishop de Isorna interjects sharply: "But Pope Martin V never fully accepted these decrees! He viewed the Council of Constance as an emergency measure during schism, not a permanent change in church governance. He believed that once the crisis passed, normal papal supremacy should resume."

The younger Bishop of Ávila speaks carefully: "And that, Your Majesty, is the heart of our current crisis. Pope Eugenius IV sees Basel as a threat to his authority. The council is demanding reforms—reduction of papal taxes, limits on papal appointments, financial accountability. The Pope views this as rebellion. The council views it as legitimate governance."

Archbishop Gutiérrez looks at you soberly: "So when you ask 'why do some Christians doubt the office of the Pope'—they don't doubt the office exists. They question whether the Pope stands above the Church, or within it subject to councils. It's a fundamental question about the very structure of Christendom."

Bishop de Cartagena adds: "And Your Majesty, there are legitimate concerns on both sides. Without strong papal authority, we risk returning to schism—local churches going their own way, unity shattered. But without conciliar checks, we risk papal tyranny—corruption, nepotism, worldly ambition unchecked."

The room falls quiet, waiting for your response to this explanation.

A heavy silence falls over the chamber. The churchmen exchange glances—some uncomfortable, others resigned. Finally, Archbishop Gutiérrez speaks with careful honesty.

He stands and moves to the window, looking out over Toledo. "The office of the papacy is sacred—the unbroken line from Saint Peter to today. But the men who hold that office remain men, subject to temptation like all of us." He turns back to you. "Pope Martin V, who blessed you so generously, was by all accounts a holy man. But even he was not above criticism. He appointed five of his own relatives as cardinals. He enriched his family, the Colonnas, beyond measure."

Bishop de Cartagena speaks gently, as if explaining something painful: "Your Majesty, in the past century alone we have seen popes who were warriors first and priests second. Pope Julius II will be remembered as much for leading armies as for spiritual leadership. Some popes have had mistresses, acknowledged bastard children, sold church offices to the highest bidder."

The Condulmer family benefits greatly from his papacy. Is that worldly ambition? Or legitimate concern for his kinsmen?"

Bishop de Isorna, the conservative, feels compelled to defend: "But Your Majesty, we must distinguish between the office and the man! Even if individual popes sin—and they do, for all have sinned and fall short—the authority of the Keys remains. Christ promised the gates of Hell would not prevail against His Church. That promise holds regardless of human weakness."

The Abbott of San Benito de Valladolid, who has been silent until now, speaks with the quiet authority of age: "Your Majesty, I am seventy-three years old. I have lived under seven popes. Some were saints. Some were scoundrels. Most were men trying their best while struggling with power, wealth, and pride." He looks at you with kind eyes. "The question before Basel is not whether popes can be corrupt—history proves they can. The question is: what structure best protects the Church when they are?"

Archbishop Gutiérrez returns to his seat. "Your Majesty, you met Pope Martin V at perhaps his finest moment—a dying man making peace with God, using his last strength to bless a true crusade. You saw the best of what the papacy can be." He pauses. "But the office has not always been held by men like that. And it may not be again."
